en.content: Arbutus unedo is an evergreen shrub or tree native to parts of the Mediterranian and Western Europe[0] often occuring as part of scrub or heathland[1]. It's commonly planted in gardens as a decorative shrub for it's vivid and glossy evergreen foliage, attractive twisting stems, and clusters of white bell-shaped flowers which develop into a bounty of fleshy round red fruits[0] 1-3cm in diameter. It succeeds in poor, even rocky, soils[1] and is well adapted to dry summer conditions[0]. Traditinally prized as a wood for charcoal production[1] and as a fruit for liquers and preserves[2].
en.license: Copyright Andru Vallance 2016. All rights reserved

en.content: *Arbutus unedo* grows to 5–10 m tall, rarely up to 15 m, with a trunk diameter of up to 80 cm. The leaves are dark green and glossy, 5–10 cm long and 2–3 cm broad, with a serrated margin. The hermaphrodite flowers are creamy white to pale pink, bell-shaped, 4–6 mm diameter, and produced in panicles of 10–30 together in autumn. The fruit is a fleshy red berry, 1–2 cm diameter, with a rough surface.

meta.notes: This text has been modified somewhat from the original. May constitute a derivative work at this point.

advice.en: The fleshy berries have been used to make preserves[0]. The pulp is very seedy and is sometimes strained to produce a sweet and delicately flavoured jelly[0].

Various traditional alcohols are produced from the berries[0], which often ferment and become slightly alchoholic before falling from the tree. Examples include the Português *medronho*[1] or the Albanian *raki*[1]
Like other plants in the family, honey from *Arbutus unedo* flowers is prized for it's dark colour and complex, bitter flavour[0].
*Arbutus unedo* wood is dense and has been traditionally used in some regions as a source of charcoal for iron smelting due to it's high burning temperature.
Despite dense attractive wood, reported uses of *Arbutus unedo* in traditional carpentry are rare due to it's growth habit of twisty stem growth and tendancy to form large radial splits while drying.

text.en_GB: The seed is best surface sown in a cold frame as soon as it is ripe. Stored seed should be soaked for 5 - 6 days in warm water and then surface sown in a shady position in a greenhouse[16]. Do not allow the compost to become dry. 6 weeks cold stratification helps[18]. The seed usually germinates well in 2 - 3 months at 20°C[18]. Seedlings are prone to damp off[19], they are best transplanted to individual pots as soon as they are large enough to handle and should be kept well ventilated. Grow them on in a greenhouse for their first winter and then plant out in late spring after the last expected frosts[1].

text.en: Basal cuttings in late winter[15], by cuttings of mature wood of the current season's growth, November/December [Britain] in a frame. Poor percentage[16].
Layering of young wood - can take 2 years[17][15]

cultivation.text:
Requires a nutrient-rich well-drained moisture-retentive soil in sun or semi-shade and shelter from cold drying winds, especially when young[20][15]. Grows well in heavy clay soils and in dry soils. Most species in this genus require a lime-free soil but this species is fairly lime tolerant[20][15]. Succeeds in fairly exposed maritime positions[21][15]. Tolerates industrial pollution[15]. Plants have withstood temperatures down to -16°c without injury at Kew[20]. They grow very well in S.W. England, fruiting well in Cornwall[22][23]. Plants resent root disturbance and are best placed in their final positions whilst young[20][18]. Give them some protection in their first winter. 
There are a number of named varieties[24] developed for their ornamental value. 'Elfin King', 'Croomei' and 'Rubra' are all small forms that fruit well when small[25]. The variety 'Rubra' was 1.2 metres tall at Kew in late 1990 and was laden down with fruits and flowers[K]. 'Elfin King' only reaches a height of 1 metre, comes into bearing when young and fruits well[24]. It is ideal for container culture[24]. 'Croomei' is said to be a more reliable fruiting form[22].
